summary.p: Other palaeographic observations. The consonants ka and ra occur in both short and long forms. Anusvāra is normally above the character to which it belongs.

handDesc.handNote: The primary hand inscribing most of the text. Tends to be rather bold, using fairly simple and slightly cursive glyph forms.

I cannot assert definitively that this is a different hand, but line 37 certainly includes a higher number of awkward characters than the rest of the text. In addition, the dependent vowel i may be formed differently here than elsewhere, and most importantly, the consonants b and especially y are drawn rather differently. My impression is that this is a less confident hand, which attempts to draw sophisticated characters with a varying degree of success, unlike the primary hand that simplifies boldly and confidently.

div.p:

app.note: It is not impossible that the character read as ta is in fact a final T.

I restore on the basis of the Nutulapaṟu grant and London Plates of Maṅgi Yuvarāja, both of which use the same wording, though for Jayasiṁha rather than Kīrtivarman. The characters indicated as tentatively read cannot be confirmed from the vestiges visible in the facsimile, but are nonetheless quite certain.

According to RM's note, ra looks like ru. However, the ū sign is curved upwards. In fact, evidently saṁ was first engraved, then corrected to ra. In addition to this character, there seems to be something added below the line at this point, just to the right of the descender of ra. The strokes visible there are probably not random damage, since the next line bends out of its way below them, so that the string ṇḍalasya in that line is slightly lowered and inclined downward, while the following śrī is at a much higher level. However, no insertion seems to be required either here or in the next line at this point. I cannot read the inserted text, if that is what it is. Its first character may be a small ṇa, and this may be followed by one to three further small characters of whose shape nothing can be discerned in the estampage.

I cannot fully reconstruct RM's reading and emendation. At the end of line 4, he apparently reads jayaśilati and emends the final vowel to ā. A footnote by his editor completes this emendation to jayāsi-latā. In line 5 it is also clear that RM emends śū to sū, but I fail to understand what he intends with the word praroha, shown in his edition in round parentheses. He probably means this to replace the preceding word he reads as praśūtāya, but if so, then I do not see why he first emends that to prasūtāya. No matter what RM intended, I am quite confident that he is mistaken. The first characters in line 5 are in my opinion not praśūtāya but praśūtāmo. Of this sequence, tāmo are at the lower edge of the binding hole, and are therefore reduced in size and distorted in shape. The scribe had thus clearly started to engrave prasūtāmoda at the edge of the plate, but then he saw that it looked awkward and noticed the mistake in śū, and re-engraved these characters. There is no visible indication that the first four characters are deleted, but this was nevertheless certainly the engraver's intent. As for line 4, jayāsi-latā is quite ingenuous and some later Eastern Cālukya inscriptions do routinely compare swords to lianas. However, the Koṇeki grant of Viṣṇuvardhana II (lines 10-11) describes Jayasiṁha I as °āneka-samara-saṁghaṭṭa-labdha-vijaya-śīlatā-prasūta-yaśaḥ-prasūtāmoda-gandhādhivāsita-sakala-dig-maṇḍalasya (where -prasūtāmoda- is probably erroneous for -prasūty-āmoda-), so the reading jaya-śīlatā can be established confidently here.

I follow RM in dismissing the second bhuja as superfluous dittography. There is a slight possibility that the first bhuja is in fact a different word beginning with bhu, and thus the second is not redundant. It is also possible that the second bhuja is not simply a product of dittography, but an erroneously engraved word influenced by the first bhuja. The Koṇeki grant of Viṣṇuvardhana II has sakala-lokāśraya-bhuja-yugaḷa-bala-namitāśeṣa- (describing Jayasiṁha), and the composer's intent may have been -bhuja-yuga- here.

I accept RM's reading, which he prints as clear. In fact, the last character of the name is far from clear. If an anusvāra is present, then it seems to be placed in the middle of the circular vowel mark for i. The vowel could equally well be read as ī. Between ma and the putative ṁgi, there is a distinct vertical stroke, as high as a character body. The body of the final character is unclear; reading it as g is possible, but if it was meant to be g, then it has probably been corrected from something else. Possibly, maghiṁ (for maṁghi) was first inscribed; compare line 20 of the Jaḷayūru grant of Viṣṇuvardhana III. Alternatively, this character may have started out as śrī or chrī (for śrīmac-chrī), in which case part of its subscript r may have been incorporated into the vowel i of sarvvān ittham below (another part being the vertical line visible after ma). Yet another alternative is that ge or go was first inscribed.

The ARIE report says the granted village is in canūṟpalli viṣaya. I believe its author must have read the locative ending pallyāṁ like I do even though RM ignores (or his edition omits) what seems to be a rather definite anusvāra at the end. As for the second character, I see no indication of u, much less of ū, in the estampage, but accept the joint testimony of two scholars who have read something of the kind here. The upper part of the third character definitely looks like ḻ, but a damaged ṟ (as read in ARIE) is not out of the question; in addition, the character could be ḫpa.
There are some extra strokes on the left side of pa, which may be remnants of a correction, e.g. from ja to pa.
The lower part of ccha is lost to the edge of the binding hole.

Although RM prints most of this text as clearly legible, the vestiges I can make out in the estampage do not confirm his reading, and though the syntax is garbled, I expect only one name here (see the note to the translation). I cannot definitively exclude RM's reading, but the first character of the sequence that I find illegible does not seem to be śa; the second could perhaps be ma or vā; and the last looks like dra or vra. The first somewhat legible character, for which I provisionally accept RM's gi, may also be dhi, vi or śi.
